image.altText: Smoke burning over homes

items.synopsis: An emergency warning is issued for two out-of-control bushfires in New South Wales which are threatening homes and properties.

title.children: Residents told it's too late to leave as two out-of-control bushfires are upgraded to emergency

image.altText: flames light up night sky behind houses

items.synopsis: Bushfire emergencies are unfolding in multiple states, with hundreds of firefighters battling blazes in Victoria while an emergency warning for Flinders Island in Tasmania's north-east has been downgraded. Follow live.

title.children: Fires in Victoria, NSW reach emergency level as Tasmanian fire downgraded

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The emergency warnings in Victorian townships Loch Sport and Seacombe have been downgraded to Advice level. "There is currently no threat to you," authorities say. "Stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. Don't get complacent, the situation may change quickly." Authorities advise residents in these areas to continue to monitor weather conditions and warnings as the fire is not yet under control. Earlier, CFA Chief Officer Jason Heffernan said while there were high winds, rain was starting to fall on the fire grounds. "I am very confident that the firefighters are doing everything they can to stop the progress and contain that fire," Heffernan said. "They are very much going to be assisted by the rainfall."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Emergency warnings in Loch Sport and Seacombe downgraded

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Georgia-Lenton-Williams Some regional community members say they can't download the Vic Emergency app because it is incompatible with their phones. Gippsland local Trevor has told ABC Statewide Drive his wife's phone was apparently too new to operate the app. “I've got a daughter and a son who live on the Briag Stratford Road… fairly close to the fire,” he said. “My wife and I, we grew up at Loch Sport and currently in Paynesville we're under flood watch, so it would be nice to have the app.” Several people have been contacting the program to report similar issues downloading the app. Emergency Management Victoria said earlier issues with the push notifications have been resolved and urge people to use multiple sources of information during emergencies.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional residents report having trouble accessing Vic Emergency app

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Bridget Murphy A large contingent of fire trucks have arrived in Kearsley, near Cessnock. Crews from Hornsby in Sydney, and other towns from the Hunter Valley region are responding to the fast moving fire. It has burned more than 100 hectares and is out of control. A fire nearby is burning at an emergency level, with residents in nearby Elrington and Abernathy told it's too late to leave, and to shelter in place.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Crews working to control 100 hectare fire in Kearsley, NSW

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

items.synopsis: The local share market falls sharply as investors bet on interest rates staying higher for longer, while the value of the Australian dollar, gold and oil suffer heavy losses. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX wipes out all its gains of 2023, RBA keeps rates on hold but doesn't rule out future increase

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares have fallen to their lowest level since March 20, with the ASX 200 down 1.3% to 6,943 points. However, the bigger picture is that the benchmark index is down 1.4% since the year began. So that means, overall, the local share market has erased all the gains it made in 2023. Healthcare was the only sector which traded higher today, driven by Neuren Pharmaceuticals (+2.3%) and CSL (+1%). On this overwhelmingly negative day, 180 out of 200 stocks finished in the red (so that's most of them). Mining and energy stocks were among the worst performers, including Sayona Mining (-9.5%), Paladin Energy (-5.9%), Beach Energy (-5.5%) and Mineral Resources (-5%). The Australian dollar also experienced heavy losses — down 0.8% to 63.12 US cents. (That's on top of the 1.1% drop it suffered overnight). So the local currency is now trading at its weakest level since November last year. Just to give you an idea of how steep that drop is, the Aussie dollar was buying 64 US cents yesterday afternoon!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX falls 1.3 per cent, closes at six-month low

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're doing it tough at the moment in this high interest rate environment (or know someone who is) there are plenty of resources available. If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access. National Debt Helpline : 1800 007 007 Mob Strong Debt Help : 1800 808 488 ASIC's Moneysmart website Australian Financial Complaints Authority Find a financial counsellor Lifeline : 13 11 14 Beyond Blue : 1300 224 636 (This is general information only, and if you require financial advice, please seek out a professional.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If you're struggling with higher interest rates, help is available

children.content: If you're doing it tough at the moment in this high interest rate environment (or know someone who is) there are plenty of resources available.
If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access.
(This is general information only, and if you require financial advice, please seek out a professional.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With the RBA leaving rates on hold at 4.1% for another month, here's what the cash rate looks like now. The cash rate is still the highest it's been since April 2012, and it's the longest pause we've seen in this current rate hiking cycle. (Should the RBA lift rates once more by the end of the year by 0.25 percentage points like economists are widely expecting, that would take the cash rate to its highest level since November 2011, when it was 4.5%.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's what the cash rate looks like now

children.content: With the RBA leaving rates on hold at 4.1% for another month, here's what the cash rate looks like now.
The cash rate is still the highest it's been since April 2012, and it's the longest pause we've seen in this current rate hiking cycle.

(Should the RBA lift rates once more by the end of the year by 0.25 percentage points like economists are widely expecting, that would take the cash rate to its highest level since November 2011, when it was 4.5%.)

image.altText: A smiling baby in a blanket.

image.altText: A man in a woven headdress stands in a field, looking solemn
